HENRY.raw_line: Smells good.Wow. Thanks. He digs in.Good. How was yours? She's still buttering the toast. Carefully.This is great. She sits down next to him. Watches him eat.Your shift's at eight thirty? She nods.You not eating?You okay?Sure. What time? Pause.Right. She just stares at him...What?Cindy and Bill are welcome here anytime. Pause.You're talking about kids.Okay.I love kids. He looks down, resumes eating. A beat.Of course I do. She looks at him.Eddie Vibes.I'm okay. What's going on?Yeah.Yeah. Eddie stares at him. Smiles.What do I say what?It's November.Oh. Beat.So where's this game?Huh.Bank robbery. MAX pulls up his pants, flushes the TOILET.But I didn't do it. Max smiles. Goes to the sink. Washes his hands.Henry.So...what are you in for?Nothing.I'm not sure.My what?Not sure I ever had one.I don't know. A pretty good one?I told you. I'm here by mistake. Max shoots a look back at him.What? Several convicts are making their way towards them... He pulls Henry close, his tone suddenly intense :I am.What tests?I don't feel good.Hi. You look beautiful.I'm okay. How about you?Okay.Oh. Pause.Okay. Wow...It's alright.No. He looks at her.I want you to be happy.Books and covers.Hector. You're up. Standing just outside, A GUARD watches the make-shift barbershop carefully. Hector takes his seat. Max wraps a sheet around his neck.Next month.Nope.I didn't do the crime.Yeah, you're right. Henry ponders.You know you never did tell me what your dream was, Max.Really?This place is horrible, Max. Max thinks, lathering his hair...When?I thought maybe this was my way out.Yeah.Yeah. Henry, silent for a moment.Maybe you should think about getting out of here sometime. I'll buy you a cup of coffee on the outside.I thought it was my dream is my truth is my destiny.I'm going to miss you.I'm still gonna miss you.Hey.Thanks.Sure.Hi. It's not so awkward.Thanks. A beat. They just stand there for a moment.Are you happy?I'm glad. He means it. Henry picks up the box, shoulders the bag.I don't know yet. Joe enters.You mean like a pyramid scheme?Yeah?I don't know your name.Right. You're welcome Joe.I'm good. How are you?Greece?I was in prison.Good. Thank you.About what?Sure. Sounds good.Thanks. She sits down at her desk.It does?Good.I think I'm okay. He grabs his thigh. Winces with pain. Tries to get up.No, don't. I think I'm okay.Yeah. Fine.Yeah.Thanks. Julie comes in.It's okay. I really am fine.No. You look familiar.What?Oh, that's why. An awkward moment.Yeah. I'm okay.Yeah.Sure.Thanks.A bathroom?Hobbles down the hallway. He notices the photos on the wall. A series of HISTORICAL SHOTS of OLD BUFFALO.Nice to see you too. He goes to hug him.I figured it out.My destiny.The bank.Yeah.The one I didn't rob. Pause.Exactly.I did the time, I may as well have done the crime.I need your help.So what do you say?You've got your review coming up --So you can get of here. If you want to.Yes, it is.Yes. It is.This is not a home. This is a prison.Max. You can't die in this place.You really want to die here?I'm asking for your help.I've thought about it. It's the right thing.Max! Max exits.Watches as Julie comes up the aisle. She notices him.No.I saw your picture outside. The door was open. I came in. She exits.Is it always like that?(gesturing back to theYeah.Looks complicated.I thought you were listening. She looks at him, curiously.I'm Henry by the way.Sure.Doesn't look like you.Oh. It's funny.Yeah. She smiles. Pierre puts the coffees down on the bar.Oh.Yeah. I guess. Pause.Why?You're leaving? She downs the last of her coffee.Appears. Smiling.I knew you could do it. Max looks around nervously.I don't have a car.Yes, it is. I'm here. I'm picking you up.Max, it's okay. You're free.Come on, Max.Take it easy. There's nothing to be frightened of. I promise. You're okay. The bus station's just a short walk. Max starts to hyperventilate :You're going to be alright.Come on, Max, we're going to miss that bus. Henry helps Max back up again.You hungry? He opens his bag and pulls out a sandwich. Offers it to him. Max doesn't say anything.It's pastrami. On rye. A beat. Max opens one eye...Here we are. Henry indicates the tiny bed in the corner of the living room. There are some second hand books on the bedside table like `Future Shock' by Alvin Toffler and Dostoyevsky.That one's yours.Anything else you need? A beat.I'm not sure, Max. But it seems to give people a lot of purpose. They walk into the Cafe Orpheum.It's a start.It's an article.No. No guns.Someone could get hurt. Pause.Maybe it's still there, Max. A beat.Maybe it is. Max looks at him.The vault is here. He walks across the alley...The tunnel runs under here... He follows it toward the back door of the theatre.And ends up somewhere in there. He turns to Max.Hi.Julie, Max. Max, Julie.Oh, we were, you know --How you doing?Sure. Go ahead. Julie and Henry watch them go.No. He's a friend.It's peaceful out here. Beat.Is it fun?Pretending to be other people. She thinks.So, in a way, you're still playing `you'.So what part of `you' are you playing now?My story?I'm figuring that out.I just got out of jail. ON JULIE. She wasn't expecting that.Sounds worse than it is.No. Do I look like one? She studies him.What do I look like? She studies him some more.I do? She laughs. Then stops. Dead serious :The Cherry Orchard. So what happens? What's it about? Is it funny? Julie gets up out of her chair.I guess it's not funny. She looks at him.Do you like Chinese?Golden Dragon?Eight o'clock?See you, Julie.You found it?Who?What about the vault?Okay. How do I look?Hi. How was rehearsal? She puts it down. No answer.Where then?I guess that's where people go.Sounds like a plan. The waitress brings over the check and the fortune cookies.We going anywhere in particular?I get it. They start to walk...I worked at a toll booth.Rainbow bridge.Yes.Yeah. She laughs.What's so funny?That's funny?I worked nights. It gave me time to think.About where I wasn't going.I'm working on it.For trying to rob the First Buffalo Bank.I thought I was on my way to a softball game. It was a mistake. Pause.But now I'm going to rob it for real.Yeah.There's a tunnel.Runs from the bank to the theatre.Yeah.What?What for?Neither can I. She gets up.`I have to go to Kharkov on the five o'clock train. Such a bother, I wanted to stay and look at you and talk to you.`Even more beautiful, and dressed like a Parisian...you could blow me down.'`Your brother says I'm an upstart, a money-grubber.'`I don't care a bit. I just want you to believe in me like the old days!'`I just want your wonderful tender eyes to look at me like they did then.'`I just want your wonderful tender eyes to look at me like they did then.' She laughs some more. Comes closer.Me too. They kiss...Good morning. She climbs on top of him. Henry smiles.Good morning.Max.It's alright. She knows.We brought breakfast. How do you like your eggs? Henry enters the kitchen...leaving Max and Julie there.Yeah. I did.It's okay, Max.How do you like your bacon?No. I like it out here.`Your brother Leonid says I'm an upstart, a money grubber...`I just want you to believe in me like the old days.'We read it last night.We were.Yeah. She downs her coffee. Stands.What?We could?It's rehearsal. There are people everywhere.What?What?What?I'm not an actor.Max. Come on.No, it doesn't.I can't be Lophakin. They have a Lophakin. Max thinks...There has to be another way. Max, frustrated :Yes. I want it.Then you're gonna be Lophakin!I read it. I think I know the scene.Your brother, Leonid ANDREYEVICH says I'm an upstart, a money grubber --A money-grubber!Your brother, Leonid Andreyevich says I'm an upstart, a money grubber. He can say whatever he likes. I don't care a bit --I just want you to believe in me like in the old days.Good God in Heaven. My father was one of your father's serfs, and your grandfather's serf before that. But you, you did so much for me in the old days that I've forgotten all that... His yearning is suddenly palpable. Intense. Tender.I love you...like a sister...more than a sister. Henry drops to his knees, supplicates.Good?I think so. A beat.You mean since you ran me over... She smiles.No.I used to sit in that toll booth and think about just getting in one of those cars, going wherever they went. Just joining someone else's life.Yeah, I was.That I was going along with everything. I didn't know I could change it.It already has. She gets the honey out of the cupboard. Pours some in her tea.Nice. A beat.Are you sure you're okay with this? I know it's a lot. She turns to him.Thanks. Thank you. Looking forward.There's still twenty feet to go. He turns back to him :We're going to need another pair of hands.That's him.Thanks for meeting us.How's your pyramid scheme?Okay. Joe hits his Schooner Longneck.Kitchenware.So how's Debbie?She's pregnant?Congratulations.Come on. This is great news. It's going to be okay.Listen, Joe, maybe we can help. A beat.We might have a job for you. Max shoots a look at Henry. Joe chugs a glass of water, looking at both of them now.There's maybe twenty feet till the bottom of that vault.So what do you think?No guns. People could get hurt.They're still guns.I like it. She looks at him.For what?I hope not.Not really, no. He thinks carefully before he says it :I don't know. Maybe I could meet you out west...Yeah. Maybe you could meet me there.Just now.Meeting me --You're not?I thought that was your plan. Do the playIs there a reason you didn't leave before?Yeah. Well. Maybe...It was just an idea. Why not --I didn't.Why couldn't I have met her after?Julie. I asked her to meet me. After we're done.She said no.Why of course?I paid already, Max.I'll check. Henry walks to the door.Who is it?Yeah. I know you.What do you want, Eddie?You can't kill him.What happened last night?We should talk about it. She turns.What's on your mind, Frank?What was her name?I'm Sorry. The moment just hangs there...Shit. ON THE MARQUEE : "Chekhov's `The Cherry Orchard'...Opens NOVEMBER 23rd, 8 PM"Opening night.That's soon.Maybe we should wait. Do it closing night.Walks back outside again. It's as if he got all the answers he needed...No. He turns to Max.I'm not leaving her.Not a cloud in the sky.You too, Max. Let's go.I want you to meet me in California.We're doing it tonight. She sits there...It's the only time we can get in theNothing's fucked up. If it's tonight or a month from now, what's the difference? I still want you to meet me.Arnold's coming back. Max arranged it already.I want us to be together. She laughs. That's so ridiculous to her.You know that's not true --Isn't she beautiful?What are you doing, Eddie? Eddie turns at him.I got shot. Henry hears the tannoy. It's his cue. He's late.I gotta get on stage. He rushes out...It's fine. Go. Joe guns it.Stop the car!Joe, stop the car.It's never been about money. You know that.Take a chance. Meet me in Moscow.That's not true. Meet me in Moscow. She tries to get away again...I can't. Pause.Meet me in Moscow. She can't move. The audience is rapt.I know.`Your brother says I'm an upstart, a money grubber...but I don't care a bit.' She laughs...they kiss in the sun for a while...

MAX.raw_line: So. What're you in for?I said what are you in for? A beat.Good. Clean. Simple. I like it. Henry just watches.Ah. Mistaken identity. A perennial favorite. Identities are just constructs, anyway. They're mistaken all the time. He dries his hands. Presents one of them to Henry.I'm Max.Go on. Make yourself at home. Henry sits down on his bed.Life. A beat. It's starting to hit Henry...Don't worry, you'll get used to it.Hurry up. We gotta go. Henry's disoriented.Breakfast. A GUARD, seeing Henry still in his bunk, bangs his baton against the bars of the cell.`Monday is whole wheat bun-day.' Henry's lost in thought...What are you thinking about?You're thinking something. Let me guess. You're thinking, `How did I get here?' Henry puts out his tray.How do you think any of us got here?I'll tell you how. Because we committed crimes. But we committed to the wrong thing. You see that was our mistake. We didn't fulfill our potential, we got angry and we took it out on other people. A bald, TATTOOED GANG-BANGER walks right past them to a table.See him?Hector. He wanted to be a doctor. He could've been, but he chose not to fulfil his potential, he chose not to commit to his dream. And now look at him.By the way, I recommend the potatoes.That's the real crime, Henry. Not committing to your dream. They begin to eat.So what's yours?Your dream.Never had a dream? What kind of a life is that?Henry, you're in jail. Henry thinks about that. Puts a piece of potato in his mouth.But here's the good news. We got all this time to do. And time is a medium of exchange. You can buy things with it.Knowledge. Self respect. Forgiveness. And in your case, you can figure out what your dream is. Max takes his arm :Your dream is your truth is your destiny. Henry looks at him.There are no mistakes. Max suddenly glimpses some activity over Henry's shoulder.But you're going to have to fight for that dream, Henry.You're at a crossroads now. There are going to be tests!This is your moment. Whatever you do now defines you. Go get em! Henry gets up : CHARGES the inmates, arms swinging, taking several down. He gives it everything he's got. They pile into him, pummeling him. Henry just keeps fighting...but it's hopeless. GUARDS rush in. Max watches.You did good, Henry.You're doing better than you feel. Henry touches his swollen eye. It stings.Go to sleep, Henry.I ever tell you I was married? Henry turns to him.I mean nearly. I had a lovely correspondence going with Jocelyn Steinberg in Utica. Problem was when she finally came on visitor's day she said I was too short. Henry thinks.Right. Books and covers.Clean as a whistle.Thank you.October.I'm working. The other INMATES egg him on.Leave me alone.All right, so I'm sitting there, and the head of the board asks me what I'm going to do if they let me out this time. And, so... Max's face starts to shudder...his shoulders jerking back a little bit...I get this twitch! and then I give him my answer: "I'm gonna break in your house, set your dog on fire, eat all your food, go on a naked rampage through your garden, dance in the streets of your l'il hometown like a crazed harpee, hurl myself headlong flaming through the ethereal sky like God's blackest angel and explode like a goddamn heavenly fireball! Eyes ablaze and face beetroot red and twitching like a mad man...Oh, yeah. You don't want ME. You don't want THIS. Not out THERE. The inmates look slightly scared. Max casually picks up his clippers and smiles :Believe me, I'm not going anywhere. They crack up. A beat.Everyone knows Henry's innocent. Laughter.I like it! `You got the time, so you may as well have done the crime!' Everyone laughs again.Now that's funny, Henry.I'm living it.Sure! It's easier to live in here. You don't have to do anything. You just show up. In fact they even do that for you. I'm living the life.So why didn't you just say something?Back then. When you had the chance. When you were still innocent.And was it?See. There are no mistakes.You got everything, kid?The only thing I've ever missed in twenty three years is a hot bath. And that ain't worth walking out of here for. The cell door slides open.Don't forget. Your dream is your myth is your truth. Pause.Just testing. Henry continues...stops at the door.Yeah, well. I hope I never see you again. Henry smiles.Get out of here, Henry.Emerges with a guard.I thought I told you I didn't want to see your face again. Henry smiles.What?Good. What is it? A beat. Henry leans in.The bank is your destiny?What bank?But you went to jail for it.What are you talking about Henry? Henry looks around. Closer --Ah, that. Time. Crime. Right.What for?I'm in Jail. That's what I say.-- So?No. It's not as simple as that.No, it's not.No, it's not.I'm happy here. This is my home.Whatever you want to call it, I'm happy here. A beat. Henry looks at Max now. He looks frail.I can die wherever I want.What do you want, Henry?To rob that bank?!Henry. I got cards.Great to see you, kid.Right.I always do, Felipe! As Max reaches the end of the walkway, an OLD GUARD opens the next steel door for him.How's your grandson?That's great. The socialization begins! The Guard smiles as he leads him toward the PAROLE BOARD ROOM at the end of another long corridor. They stop at the door.As many as it takes.
